column13: If you are a victim of abuse, report it to the police.  Remember: a protection order can prevent more violence. Violence can mean intimidation, physical, sexual or verbal abuse, being threatened with abuse or when you lose your freedom. Abuse can happen when men feel angry or powerless. Get free legal help from selected women and childrenâ€™s organisations or call the toll-free helpline on 0800-150-150 for help and counselling.

column13: Valid permit holders are safe from arrest/detention unless you break the law. There are other exceptional circumstances. Police/immigration officials may request proof of your regularised stay in SA, or you may be arrested/detained. If arrested, you must prove you're allowed to be in SA with a valid visa. You'll go to a police station until the DHA verifies your ID within 48hrs. Never bribe an officer to avoid being arrested or get out of jail. This is against the law!

column13: There are legal ways out of your arrest. It may take time. Ask to speak to a lawyer. It is your right.  If you are arrested and have a valid visa, ask a friend or family to give copies of your valid documents to the DHA. Remember: You have the right to get legal representation if you are arrested. Tip: If you go to a magistrateâ€™s court, you can ask for â€˜legal aidâ€™. You will be able to speak to a lawyer for free.

column13: The immigration/DHA officer should verify your documents in 48hr or release you. You must carry your docs on you or the officer must help you find it. You have the right to a phone call to get copies of your permit. The officer must try to confirm your status with the DHA. Itâ€™s your right to write a statement to the DHA if you disagree with the decision to detain/deport you. You canâ€™t be detained for more than 30 days unless the court has a warrant. You may write a statement to the judge. The court must inform you of its decision in writing.

Ask your family to notify Lawyers for Human Rights about your situation and that you need help. Contact Lawyers for Human Rights if your conditions of detention are unsafe or violate your dignity.

column13: Migrants with foreign nursing qualifications must register with the South African Nursing Council (SANC). Visit www.sanc.co.za for a list of documents you'll need to submit. If you're already registered back home, you need a SANC affidavit. Your qualification and experience will be evaluated. If you meet the SANC requirements, you must write an entry exam based on your area of competence. If your application is successful, you must submit a registration form and pay a fee.

column13: The Department of Health (DOH) employs foreign doctors with the right qualifications and experience in government hospitals. To register, contact the DOHâ€™s Foreign Workforce Management Programme (FWMP) on 012-312-0467. To register, you need a job offer from a government hospital or health department. Apply for a formal endorsement from FWMP. When you have a job offer and endorsement, apply to register with the Health Professions Council of SA (HPCSA): 012-338-9350.

column13: There are laws in SA that protect you from discrimination or unfair treatment when you are at work. Your employer canâ€™t discriminate against you because youâ€™re an immigrant. The law protects you from unfair treatment. The law also protects your minimum working hours, leave, salary and the way you are dismissed.

column13: You can claim from the UIF if you end up unemployed because youâ€™re sick or have a baby. You need a 13-digit ID number to claim. If you are hurt or become infected with a disease at work and you end up being disabled, the Compensation Fund will pay out money. If you die because of your injuries your dependants will get money. The Compensation Fund will help to pay the medical bills.

column13: Apply for a medical visa in your country before you travel to SA to get medical care. See 'Temporary Visa' section for info. Remember: this visa doesnâ€™t mean you will get free health care. You'll have to pay for it yourself. Already in SA with a visa? column13: People from SADC countries pay the same medical fees as SA nationals. As a SADC national, your healthcare payments will be based on how much you earn. Take the following with you to the hospital: ID; appointment card; payslip/proof of salary; proof of address. If you donâ€™t have the right documents or if you're a non-SADC national, you'll pay the highest fees.

column13: Clinics provide treatment/medicine, mostly free. Make an appointment at your nearest clinic, unless itâ€™s an emergency. Take your valid Section 22/24 permit. If youâ€™re still waiting for yours, ask an NGO for a letter (see â€˜Useful Servicesâ€™). To go to hospital, you need a letter from the clinic unless itâ€™s an emergency. Canâ€™t pay the public hospital fees? Get an affidavit from the police to explain, or contact an NGO. DONâ€™T go to a private Dr/hospital if you canâ€™t pay the fees.

column13: Suffering traumatic events (abuse/violence/natural disaster) can lead to Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). Signs of PTSD: struggling to sleep/concentrate; nightmares; flashbacks; anxiety; helplessness; fear. Share your story if you have PTSD. In counselling youâ€™ll talk about your experience/feelings. Visit the Trauma Clinic in Joburg or Trauma Centre for Survivors of Violence & Torture in Cape Town. There are other trauma clinics in SA. See â€˜Contact Listâ€™ for more info.

column13: HIV can go unnoticed for up to 10yrs. Know your status and get treatment sooner to help you lead a normal life. HIV weakens your bodyâ€™s power to fight infections such as pneumonia. There is no cure. You can get HIV by having unprotected sex or using unsterilised needles/syringes. If youâ€™re HIV+ & pregnant, your baby can get HIV in the womb, after birth or by breastfeeding. Tip: You canâ€™t get HIV through casual contact, like working together, kissing, or sharing space.

To know your HIV status you must get a blood test, available for free at most public health centres. Youâ€™ll receive counselling before and after your test. Sometimes two tests are done. Youâ€™ll know your status after 20 minutes. Your blood sample might have to go to a laboratory. Youâ€™ll only know your status in a few days. HIV tests are very accurate. Many organisations in SA offer HIV tests, counselling and treatment. Go to www.tac.org.za or the contact list for more info.

column13: Pregnant women with HIV should ask for Nevirapine at public health centres. It can prevent HIV infection during childbirth. Nevirapine is an antiretroviral drug (ARV). Go to the contact list or www.tac.org.za for info on centres with ARV treatments.

column13: ARV treatment begins during a serious HIV-related illness or when your CD4 count drops below 350. Most people start ARV 8-10 years after infection. It isnâ€™t the same for all. See a doctor and get the best treatment for you! Remember: It doesnâ€™t matter what your document status is - you are entitled to free ARV treatment.

column13: If you wish to report a rape, go straight to the police. Donâ€™t shower, drink liquids or use the toilet â€“ this helps with evidence. You CAN change clothes, but take along the clothes you were wearing. You donâ€™t need to report it to get medical treatment. If HIV negative before the assault, you have a right to a 28-day course of antiretrovirals to prevent HIV, but must take it within 72hrs. Help/info: LoveLife 0800-121-900; AIDS Helpline 0800-01-23-22; AIDS Hotline 0800-11-0605

column13: Everyone has the right to basic education in SA. You must have a valid study permit to study in SA. In SA on another valid permit? Check first if your permit allows you to study in SA. Some conditions might apply.

column13: A creche is a preschool daycare centre for ages 1-6. Primary school: 7-13. Secondary school (academic or technical): 13-19. If you can't pay the fee, ask to work in exchange for a cheaper fee. Your child must have a visa and passport to be in SA. Children in SA must go to school â€“ itâ€™s the law. Tip: School age groups are flexible, so a child might be older than their classmates, but most government schools don't allow students to be 2yrs older than the gradeâ€™s age group.

column13: Your child must have at least a birth certificate, clinic card or old report card to register.  There'll be conditions for your child to attend school during your stay in SA. Register for a primary school closest to your house. English not good? Take a friend with who can help. Schools get full quickly so apply early (from July). If the school closest to your house is full, the school must show you another school that can help. If you struggle to register, the school close to your house must refer you to the Dept. of Education (DOE). If the school refuses admission, ask for a letter on their letterhead signed by the principal and take it to the DOE. Still canâ€™t find a school? Contact a social service provider for education or LHR. More info on the contact list.

column13: If you canâ€™t pay school fees, ask the school to reduce them by completing an exemption form. You must show proof of income (payslip/affidavit/letter of support) & give info on your expenses & responsibilities. Apply for exemption at the start of each term. Keep all letters & appointments with the school. If you ignore notices the school can make you pay. Find a NGO in the contact list for help with the form. Uniforms & learning materials also cost money. If you canâ€™t afford a uniform, your child can wear clothes that resemble it, but must still go to school. Second-hand uniforms are cheaper. Ask at the school. You shouldnâ€™t pay a registration fee. Public schools canâ€™t ask your child to leave if you canâ€™t pay.

column13: Children with special learning needs can go to a special education school. Contact the Departmenr of Education and ask about schools. Placing your child in a special education school is a long process. Get your child on a waiting list as soon as possible.

column13: You can study at a university to further your education or change your education from your home country to a SA degree. A university degree can help you to get into the SA job market. Remember: You must have a valid study permit to study in SA, you'll need to apply at the tecknikon or university before you come to SA.

column13: You need to pay an international registration & fee as an international student. Each university has thier own processes and will advise you when you apply to study there.

column13: You must be 16 years or older with a valid passport and visa. You must have proof of residence: a rental contract, telephone/utility bill in your name. You need to prove your income with a payslip or affidavit. It may be difficult to open a bank account in SA. Even if you have the right documents, the bank can decide if they want to give you an account or not. You can also ask a legal counsellor to assist.

column13: SAâ€™s constitution protects the rights of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender individuals (LGBTI). LGBT victims of unjust treatment must go to the police. LGBT victims of hate speech may lay a complaint with the SAHRC or approach the Equality Court for relief.

column13: The Refugee act states that the LGBTI group can get protection if they are persecuted for their sexual orientation. Donâ€™t be afraid to disclose your sexual orientation when applying for asylum. The RRO must treat your claim with confidentiality.

column13: Abuse is illegal in SA. Get free legal help from selected women and childrenâ€™s organisations or call the toll-free helpline on 0800-150-150 for help and counselling.

column13: Women and children have the right to live free from physical, verbal or sexual abuse. All types of abuse must be reported to the police. Remember: a protection order can prevent more violence. Violence can mean intimidation, physical, sexual or verbal abuse, being threatened with abuse or when you lose your freedom. Abuse by men or women is not acceptable and you can report them.

column13: If you or your child suffers from abuse, you must report it to the police. The police will open a criminal case. You must make a statement. Youâ€™ll get a case number. An officer will investigate your case. Some police stations have special units for domestic violence, sexual offences and child protection. Go to a police station close to your home. If you donâ€™t, your case will take longer to process. Youâ€™ll go for a medical examination and counseling.

column13: If youâ€™re afraid of more violence or feel threatened, you can go to court and get a protection order. You donâ€™t need a lawyer. A protection order can order your abuser to stop abusing you, to stay away from you or force him/her out of your home. Documents like medical reports and photos of your injuries can help your abuse case.  If thereâ€™s enough proof of abuse, youâ€™ll get an interim protection order and suspended warrant of arrest.

column13: If the abuser disobeys the order, you can get him/her arrested. Youâ€™ll need to go back to court a second time. Your abuser must also be there. The court will listen to your case. The court may give you a final protection order. If your abuser disobeys the order, he/she can get arrested.

column13: Human trafficking is a form of modern-day slavery where people are taken to another country under a false act. Theyâ€™re exploited, can't leave and are tricked with false promises of good jobs and better lives. They're forced to work in brutal and inhumane conditions. Traffickers are dangerous and shouldnâ€™t be confronted. Call the International Organisation for Migration (0800-555-999) or go to a police station if you know of someone who has been trafficked.

column13: Children without a parent or guardian must be referred to the Department of Social Development. A social worker will be assigned to the child. The social worker will go to the Childrenâ€™s Court. The court will confirm if the child is in need of care.

column13: The social worker will verify the childâ€™s placement in a temporary place of safety. A report must be compiled. If the child is a migrant, the social worker must try to find and reunite the family in the country of origin. If the family canâ€™t be located and the child canâ€™t be returned home, you must contact a legal counsellor. This is important: children must get documented as soon as possible, otherwise they risk becoming stateless.

column13: Xenophobia is an irrational hatred towards foreigners or an unreasonable fear or hatred of the unfamiliar persons. If you are a victim of xenophobic attacks, you must report it to the police. Go to the police station closest to your home. You must explain in detail what happened. The police will open a case. You will get a case number. Keep it safe! If youâ€™ve lost your document, get an affidavit from the police that explains your situation. Go to the RRO for a new permit.

column13: A stateless person doesnâ€™t have citizenship in any country. You are also at risk of being stateless if your nationality status is undecided. Not all undocumented persons are considered stateless, e.g. when your birth isnâ€™t registered or if you donâ€™t have a birth certificate, ID or passport.

column13: An undocumented personâ€™s risk of being stateless increases when you belong to a certain category or when certain factors are present like: birth outside your parentsâ€™ country of nationality; death or desertion of your parent(s); Irregular migration across international borders; mixed nationality of your parents; loss of clinic cards or records; If youâ€™re close to an international border with high cross-border movement; when the law doesnâ€™t permit dual nationality.

column13: A birth certificate proves your place of birth and identifies your parent/s. Itâ€™s the most important proof of your nationality. South African citizens born outside SA are entitled to a SA birth certificate. Foreign children born in SA are entitled to a birth certificate, but this doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re South African citizens. Children born in SA must be registered within 30 days. If you were born in SA, apply for late birth registration. Applications close in December 2015.

column13: You have a claim to SA citizenship if you: were born to a parent with SA citizenship at the time of your birth; were born in SA to a parent who was a permanent resident of SA at the time of your birth and if you lived in SA until the age of 18; have been adopted by a SA citizen; applied for and received a certificate of naturalisation from the DHA; were born in SA and have no other citizenship, nationality or right to other citizenship or nationality.
